bibl.title: Letter from Lunsford D. Fricks to Henry Rose Carter, January 17, 1922

div1.p: Fricks believes that Carter's malaria abstracts are very important to field workers, but should be issued by the Division of Scientific Research.

div1.head: Letter from Lunsford D. Fricks to Henry Rose Carter, January 17, 1922
div1.opener:
F.I. - Malaria
Room 17 Court House
N. N. C.
Abstracts
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
JC
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
Memphis, Tennessee,
January 17, 1922.
Malaria Abstracts.
Asst. Surgeon-General H. R. Carter,
U. S. Public Health Service,
2121 California St., N.W.,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Doctor:
div1.p:
Replying to your inquiry of January 14th
relative to malaria abstracts which are being made
by you and sent out from the Bureau as a part of
the weekly engineering abstracts:

I consider that your comments are very
important and that the dry abstracts without these
comments would be of considerably less value to us
in the field. My only comment would be that since
many of the subjects dealt with by you have nothing
to do with sanitary engineering, that it would be
more appropriate if your malaria abstracts were is-
sued as coming from the Division of Scientific
Research and forming a supplement or addition to
the engineering abstracts from Dr. McLaughlin's
Division. Perhaps such an arrangement, however,
is not practicable.

With best wishes and kindest regards, I
am
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, L. D. Fricks, Surgeon,
Medical Officer in Charge. Answer
